title: Meyer Desert Formation biota
text:
The Meyer Desert Formation biota is a <a href="fossilized">fossilized</a> <a href="biota%20%28ecology%29">biota</a> (<a href="flora">flora</a> and <a href="fauna">fauna</a>) found in the <a href="Dominion%20Range">Dominion Range</a> in the <a href="Transantarctic%20Mountains">Transantarctic Mountains</a> in <a href="Antarctica">Antarctica</a>, alongside the <a href="Beardmore%20Glacier">Beardmore Glacier</a>.
Since about 15 million years ago (Ma), Antarctica has been mostly covered with ice.
Fossil "<a href="Nothofagus">Nothofagus</a>" leaves in the <a href="Meyer%20Desert%20Formation">Meyer Desert Formation</a> of the <a href="Sirius%20Group">Sirius Group</a> show that intermittent warm periods allowed "Nothofagus" shrubs to cling to the <a href="Dominion%20Range">Dominion Range</a> as late as 3–4 Ma (mid-late <a href="Pliocene">Pliocene</a>). After that the <a href="Pleistocene">Pleistocene</a> glaciation covered the whole continent with ice and destroyed all major plant life on it.
Species reported by Ashworth and Cantrill from about 3 million years ago include:
